description:
Akito doesn't want to fight. Despite a childhood spent on the anime Gekiganger 3, a Mecha show, he'd rather cook than pilot a Mecha. Fate intervenes when his home on Mars is destroyed, and he is transported instantly to the Earth, mysteriously. He has questions no one can answer fully, but follows a girl from a chance meeting in hopes to discover any. The girl, Yurika, is captain of the private battleship Nadesico, and in order to follow her, he enlists as their cook. Possessing the nanite implants that allow to control mechas, he's a handy backup pilot for the mechas of the Nadesico. He joins a crew bent on revenging Mars and composed of misfits, otakus, and ditzes. But in reality they are handpicked experts. They take their own private war back to Mars to face the harsh reality that life may not always be like a Giant Mecha Series.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Female Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several female characters who are romantically interested in them.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Food
tags.description: Centers around cooking or food appraisal.

tags.name: Otaku Culture
tags.description: Centers around the culture of a fanatical fan-base.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

node.description:
__Height:__ 158 cm

[Profile (Aoni)](https://www.aoni.co.jp/search/kuwashima-houko.html) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/roudokuya_dajai) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houko_Kuwashima) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/桑島法子)

Houko Kuwashima is a Japanese voice actress and singer. She is capable of playing a variety of roles, ranging from young boys to feminine women. Kuwashima is currently affiliated with Aoni Production. Her first major role was as Yurika Misumaru in Martian Successor Nadesico.

__Non-anime roles:__
- Android 21 - Dragon Ball FighterZ (VG)
- Presea Combatir - Tales of Symphonia (VG)
- Serenica - Dragon Quest XI S: Echoes of an Elusive Age - Definitive Edition (VG)
- Kasumi - Dead or Alive series (VG)
- Roselinde Freya - Shining Blade (VG)
- Mei Ling - Metal Gear Series (VG)
- Jingliu - Honkai: Star Rail (VG)
- Ries Argent - The Legend of Heroes Series (VG)

Tomoko Kawakami was a Japanese voice actress. Having graduated from the Toho Gakuen College of Drama and Music, she was affiliated with Production Baobab at the time of her death.

In August 2008, Kawakami was diagnosed with ovarian cancer, which required surgery. During a three-year battle with cancer, most of her ongoing roles were replaced by other voice actresses, although the latter was able to do some voice work until her retirement in the start of the 2010s decade. She died on June 9, 2011 at the age of 41.

Wife of voice actor [Yuji Ueda](https://anilist.co/staff/95058/Yuuji-Ueda)

__Non-anime roles:__
~!Alex in "Totally Spies!" (animated TV series) (Japanese)  
Bimba in "Breath of Fire III: Drama Album" (Drama) (Japanese)  
Kakurine in "Eretzvaju (Evil Zone)" (VG) (Japanese)  
Mag Launcher in "Evolution 2: Far Off Promise" (VG) (Japanese)  
Majic Lin in "Majutsushi Orphen" (VG)  
Meredy in "Tales of Eternia" (VG) (Japanese)  
Meril in "Odin Sphere" (VG) (Japanese)  
Momoko Ando in "True Love Story 2" (VG) (Japanese)  
Pai-Siang in "Galaxy Fraulein Yuna 3: Final Edition" (VG) (Japanese)  
Pai-Siang in "Galaxy Fraulein Yuna 3: Lightning Angel" (VG) (Japanese)  
Ruri Hoshino in "Super Robot Wars Impact" (VG/PS2) (Japanese)  
Ruri Hoshino in "Super Robot Wars MX" (VG/PS2) (Japanese)  
Satsuki Yumiduka in "Melty Blood: ReAct" (VG) (Japanese)  
Tamami Konno in "Tokimeki Memorial Girl's Side" (VG) (Japanese)  
Xiaomu in "Mugen no Frontier - Super Robot Taisen OG Saga" (VG) (Japanese)  
Xiaomu in "Namco X Capcom" (VG) (Japanese)!~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kia_asamiya) | [Blog](https://minkara.carview.co.jp/userid/518151/blog/)

Real name is Kikuchi Michitaka, which he uses when doing character design or animation work. Best known for the 12 volume manga Silent Mobius, which has been adapted as two anime films, and later a separate series. Also made a parallel manga version of Martian Successor Nadesico called Meteor Schlachtschiff Nadesico. Already a fan of western pop culture, moved to America and got employed by Marvel on the X-Men comic, but also continues his own work.

He is a member of the manga studios [Lab Garnier](https://twitter.com/Lab_garnier) and [Studio Tron](http://www.tron.co.jp/top.html).

__[Website](http://goto.cute.or.jp)__

Gotou began his career as an animator at Atorie. After the closing of Atorie, he worked for other studios such as Project Team Muu and Fenx before going freelancer. He serves as character designer, animation director and animator on countless anime series and contributes to a monthly comic strip to Newtype magazine.

He has been an animator since he graduated from high school at 18. Unlike most other animators Gotou had never gone to an art school. He became interested in animation after seeing an advertisement in an animation magazine saying that animators were needed. Without having any connections within the industry he went on and joined Atelier Giga and studied there for a year under [Akihiko Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/103299/) before marking his debut as animator on [Mister Ajikko](https://anilist.co/anime/3437/).

In 1988 Studio Atelier declared bancrupcy and he went to Project Team Muu, which later became Phoenix Entertainment. His first work there was as animator on Anime Sanjushi. When working on the Yuusha Saga, he met Ishida Atsuko on Densetsu no Yuusha Da Garn, who influenced Gotou in his character design, particularly the design of the eyes. Together with the experience from training under Yamashita Akihiko this influence resulted in Gotou's so called "gocky picture" later.

He made his debut as character designer on Choujin Densetsu Urotsukidouji 4 and his debut as series director on Kiddy Grade.

Married to [Megumi Kadonosono](https://anilist.co/staff/100963/).

(Source: Anidb)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kawasak54965532)

Hiroyuki Kawasaki is a screenwriter and novelist.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/116444028) | [Website](http://www.dragon-brave.com)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/116444028) | [Website](http://www.dragon-brave.com)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/116444028) | [Website](http://www.dragon-brave.com)
Birthplace: Tokyo, Japan Website (artist page) Oomori Toshiyuki is a Japanese composer, arranger, pianist and musician.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/石井明治)

Freelancer with deep ties to [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

Kiyoshi Yoshida is a japanese music composer, arranger, producer, synthesizer operator, he’s especially well known for his works blending the sound of synthesizer and Wadaiko very well.    In 1985, Mr. Yoshida went to America and studied contemporary and film music at Berklee College of Music. In 1987, he came back to Japan and then started composing music for many CM, TV/Film, New Age Soundtracks.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/123099499)

Matt Greenfield is the American co-founder of the now defunct ADV Films. Originally an avid fan who ran an anime club in Houston, Texas with David Williams (known as "Anime NASA"). He, Williams and [John Ledford](https://anilist.co/staff/102621/) founded ADV Films in 1992, which began as an importer of anime, marketing primarily to the existing network of anime fans. He was married to ADV contractor and voice actress [Tiffany Grant](https://anilist.co/staff/95145).

In the English-language dubs of the ADV's licensed releases, he serves as an ADR director and occasionally takes on background roles as a voice actor, going by the pseudonym Brian Granveldt.

He continues to write and produce English dubs for new companies and distributors such as Sentai Filmworks and Section23 Films via post-production house/dubbing studio Seraphim Digital.

Matt Greenfield is the American co-founder of the now defunct ADV Films. Originally an avid fan who ran an anime club in Houston, Texas with David Williams (known as "Anime NASA"). He, Williams and [John Ledford](https://anilist.co/staff/102621/) founded ADV Films in 1992, which began as an importer of anime, marketing primarily to the existing network of anime fans. He was married to ADV contractor and voice actress [Tiffany Grant](https://anilist.co/staff/95145).

In the English-language dubs of the ADV's licensed releases, he serves as an ADR director and occasionally takes on background roles as a voice actor, going by the pseudonym Brian Granveldt.

He continues to write and produce English dubs for new companies and distributors such as Sentai Filmworks and Section23 Films via post-production house/dubbing studio Seraphim Digital.

Grandson of composer Ryoichi Hattori and son of composer Katsuhisa Hattori, Takayuki Hattori started out his career as a music arranger for Masashi Sada before given his big break by being allowed to compose Godzilla vs. SpaceGodzilla (1994), after Akira Ifukube turned down the oppurtinty. Hattori's body of work tends to be diverse, ranging from comedies like Welcome Back, Mr. McDonald (1997) to Toei's movie adaption of the GTO TV drama series.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/加戸誉夫)

Currently part of [Studio Mother](https://anilist.co/studio/6638/). Former long-time member of [Xebec](https://anilist.co/studio/27/). Originally from [Ashi Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/196/), which he joined after graduating from Osaka University of Arts in 1985.
Representative director of Production Ai.

A highly prolific and an extremely influential animator.

Know for his experimentation with the timing of keyframes, his dynamic poses, and his peculiar effects Kanada pioneered a number of techniques and concepts that permeated and shaped the Japanese animation industry, influencing not only his peers but also the generations to come.

Kanada's ability and his tendency to be very personal with his drawings, even to the point of ignoring storyboards if the situation required, popularized in the industry the concept of letting the individual animator's talents shine instead of being uniformed into anonymity. This precept is still respected today and it's one of the reasons Japanese animation is so distinctly unique. His career is also a testament to his ethos that expressive and vibrant animation is not achieved simply through increasing the number of frames but through playing with movement, poses and timing.

In the early '00s, Kanada became an employee at Square Enix.

Notable Square Enix titles in which he was credited:

~!
- 2002, Final Fantasy XI (Motion Capture, Animation Director)
- 2005, Musashiden II: Blade Master (Storyboard)
- 2006, Dawn of Mana (Facial Setting)
- 2007, Final Fantasy 4 DS Version (Storyboard)
- 2009, Final Fantasy XIII (Storyboard Director) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2011, Final Fantasy XIII-2 (Storyboard) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2012, Dragon Quest X (Storyboard)  - *Posthumous credit.* !~

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/荒川稔久)

Married to fellow scriptwriter [Hiroko Naka](https://anilist.co/staff/181820/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/johnsama) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/75255)

Noted for his work in the [Sword Art Online](https://anilist.co/anime/11757/) franchise.

Married to fellow animator [Haruko Iizuka](https://anilist.co/staff/105678/).
__Mika Akitaka__ is a Japanese illustrator, game creator and character, mechanical and prop designer

He is an animator and character designer. Motohashi started working at Studio Z. Later, after leaving Studio Z, he started together with Hirayama Satoshi and Kamegaki Hajime Studio Z5. Today he is affiliated with Xebec and is the representative director of its subsidiary Xebec M2.
